skill.name: esm
skill.description: Comprehensive toolkit for protein language models including ESM3 (generative multimodal protein design across sequence, structure, and function) and ESM C (efficient protein embeddings and representations). Use this skill when working with protein sequences, structures, or function prediction; designing novel proteins; generating protein embeddings; performing inverse folding; or conducting protein engineering tasks. Supports both local model usage and cloud-based Forge API for scalable inference.

content.user_title: Generate and design proteins with ESM
content.value_statement: Protein engineering requires specialized AI models to analyze sequence-structure-function relationships. ESM provides state-of-the-art protein language models for generating novel sequences, predicting structures, and designing functional proteins through multimodal AI.
actual_capabilities: Generate novel protein sequences using ESM3 masked language modeling
Predict 3D protein structures from amino acid sequences
Perform inverse folding to design sequences for target structures
Generate protein embeddings with ESM C for ML downstream tasks
Batch process proteins via Forge API for scalable inference
limitations: Requires GPU for local model inference (esm3-sm-open-v1)
Larger ESM3 models (7B, 98B) require Forge API access
Designed for research use; requires experimental validation
Generated sequences need wet-lab verification for production use

use_cases.title: Design novel proteins
use_cases.description: Generate new protein sequences with desired properties using ESM3 multimodal generation across sequence, structure, and function tracks.

use_cases.title: Screen protein variants
use_cases.description: Create and analyze libraries of protein variants using embeddings for clustering and similarity analysis.

use_cases.title: Predict structures
use_cases.description: Predict 3D structures from sequences or design sequences for known structures using inverse folding.

prompt_templates.title: Generate sequence
prompt_templates.prompt: Generate a 200-amino acid protein sequence for a fluorescent protein using ESM3. Start with a masked sequence and use function conditioning for green fluorescent protein properties.

prompt_templates.title: Predict structure
prompt_templates.prompt: Predict the 3D structure for this protein sequence using ESM3 structure track. Output the coordinates and save as PDB format.

prompt_templates.title: Inverse fold
prompt_templates.prompt: Load this PDB structure and use inverse folding to generate a sequence that folds to the target structure. Use temperature 0.7 for diversity.

prompt_templates.title: Embed sequences
prompt_templates.prompt: Generate ESM C embeddings for these protein sequences and compute pairwise similarity using cosine similarity. Cluster similar sequences together.

output_examples.input: Design a novel enzyme with catalytic activity using ESM3
output: Predicted structure shows typical enzyme fold
Chromophore region designed with catalytic residues

output_examples.input: Find similar proteins to this sequence using embeddings

output: Generated novel sequence matching the fold

best_practices: Start with smaller models (esm3-sm-open-v1) for prototyping before production
Use temperature scheduling (high to low) for better generation quality
Validate generated sequences with structure prediction before experimental work
Cache embeddings for repeated analyses to reduce compute costs
anti_patterns: Using generated proteins directly in clinical applications without validation
Ignoring biosafety considerations when designing novel proteins
Processing extremely long sequences without chunking strategies
Skipping error handling for GPU memory errors and API rate limits

faq.question: What models are available locally vs via API?
faq.answer: esm3-sm-open-v1 (1.4B) and ESM C models run locally. Larger ESM3 models (7B, 98B) require Forge API access.

faq.question: What are typical sequence length limits?
faq.answer: ESM C supports up to 1024 residues efficiently. ESM3 handles similar lengths with chunking for longer sequences.

faq.question: Can this integrate with my existing ML pipeline?
faq.answer: Yes, ESM C embeddings work as features for classifiers, clustering, and custom neural networks.

faq.question: Is my protein data sent to external servers?
faq.answer: Only when using Forge API. Local models process data on your infrastructure.

faq.question: Why is my GPU running out of memory?
faq.answer: Use half precision (.half()), process in batches, clear CUDA cache, or use smaller model sizes.

faq.question: How does this compare to AlphaFold?
faq.answer: ESM3 combines sequence generation with structure prediction in one model. AlphaFold is primarily structure prediction from sequence.
